So, we do it in other ways. For example, we have a walk and talk programme where we go out and about and we spend 20 minutes or half an hour walking with young people. There are other creative methodologies that have similar effects as sport on mental well-being. For young people we engage them in filmmaking programmes and arts programmes as well. There is something for everybody, whether it is sports or an alternative. It could be through drama too. We are still trying to support young people in their interests but we do not want to discourage those who are-----

I think the word "sport" can put a lot of people off, children and older people, everybody basically, if they do not have that competitive gene. People assume that sport is always competitive but it is absolutely not. I suppose it is about the movement piece and physical activity more so than sport.
Yes the physical activity.
Sometimes sport can equate with winning, and we know it is not all about that. Did Mr. FitzGerald want to come in here?

On the sports the Senator actually touched on the point I was going to make about winning. Sometimes we have to think about why young people drop out of sport. Is it body image? Is it the fact that it was an uber-competitive environment where they were told they needed to be playing for X team or Y team to be worthy or deemed worthy? We would often try to bring youth work methodologies into sport. We have done some programmes where we have used football as a kind of a tool to consider decision-making. We have good collaborations with some partners the UK with Queens Park Rangers Football Club. That is a brilliant initiative. With the sport thing it also creates those non-pressurised environments. We would do football leagues as well. In the north-east inner city we link in with Bohemians Football Club and with people who are community minded and really focused on young people. It is sport but it is also connection with the community. From my own time as youth justice worker I remember I was in the north-east inner city and when a young person said they were getting into boxing, which is obviously such a draw, then you know there will be discipline, decision-making, critical thinking, time management, impulse control and all of those key things, as well as physically moving the body, being fit and the serotonin going to the brain. The sweet spot is when we know the why behind the sport as well as actually them saying "I feel great because I have engaged", which is a huge protective factor against drugs. We know that.

On a broader level the definition of sport needs to be looked at. I always think that. Dancing, baton twirling and the acro that the young girls are doing now should all be classed as sport because the person is getting their serotonin. The physical health is obviously improving but the mood is as well. Does anyone else want to come in on that?

We work a lot through sport in terms of young people's development and young people's interests. Very often we have sport opportunities going on. There could be ten days of a particular sport or whatever. We also link in with the local sports clubs that young people were part of or dropped out from. We try to reintegrate them and we try to support that reintegration. We have working collaborations with the sports around summer programmes and things like that. We would use the facilities and reintroduce them to it.

As the lads were saying, we do a lot around the other alternative exercises like dance and all that. We are also trying to educate young people around functional exercise such as getting their steps in, walking to school instead of getting a lift, walking up and down the stairs, and things we do in our everyday life where we are not aware that we are actually up and active, so that young people are aware of that. Even if it is going for a walk with their friends instead of talking to them from their bedrooms while they are in their bedroom on the phone. We kind of get that going. I do believe that sport is really important.

We also work with young people around going to the gym, girls and young men as well. We have set up our first gym in one of our centres. We are trialling it there to see if it works. It is basic but everything is there that one would need for fitness and in trying to build muscle, which the boys are really interested in, but the girls are as well. We try to do that as well.

The drugs workers do education and awareness programmes with our local sports clubs. It is not only in terms of delivering drugs education. That is at a certain level but it is also about building the relationship and the connection so if someone develops an issue or they know someone in their family who already has an issue they have a name and a face now and a place to go. This is a critical part of making those links at community level and connections at community level. It is essential. Good youth workers work around a young person's timetable for sports because they are not able to move the timetable. We do that really well. We will move and adjust our group times and our programme times to ensure that consistency and that sustainability in their sport. It is really important.

We have talked a lot today about the real coalface of work that is going on in drug prevention and education but what is really important around that prevention piece is that we that we do not lose sight of sport and physical activity in the pro-social way of keeping kids away from that lifestyle.

That is really essential. On the part of the Belvedere Youth Club and the Diamond Project in the north inner city it is not just sports stars that came through their programmes. Movie stars such as Barry Keoghan and a whole range also came through.

That was something I was going to share and I was thinking "No I won't". Troy Parrott came through the club and he used to take penalties in the hall. When we were watching him on the telly I was wondering if he was thinking of the Belvo hall at all when he was taking his penalty. I was not in the Belvo at the time but I was told that Barry Keoghan actually started off in the sports hall and he was not very good so he was encouraged into the creative arts section where they did drama and dance. He actually did his first musical in Belvedere Youth Club. He had the role of Link Larkin in Hairspray. So, yes, it is different strokes for different folks.
Exactly. Every kid is not going to want to do the same type of activity but whatever they find to engage their minds and their bodies-----
And to support them in that and to nurture that.
Absolutely, yes, to nurture. That is the right word, "nurture". It is about nurturing them away from the other route.

I feel very privileged to work with a colleague, Bridie Flood, who played for the Irish international team. She is one of the first Irish women to have graced the grass at Wembley Stadium. She is a true asset for any young person coming through the door of the Belvedere Youth Club and into the Diamond Project for sports. We work with a lot of young people who, unfortunately due to their behaviour, we are advocating for them to get them back into a club. There may have been be word on the ground that the young person was involved in something at the weekend, or perhaps it was heard that such a thing happened in a community. We do not know if they have their place back on the team. That would be the 12-year-olds to 18-year-olds. With the 18-year-olds to 24-year-olds, for example, I worked with a young lad who played and he got trials for Oldham Football Club and he had played with Troy Parrott, so there are two sides of the spectrum there. When a young person comes in the door it is great to see them but I say to them that I hope they did not come here on their scooter as they should be walking and picking up their steps.
One hundred per cent.
The scooters mean they are lacking exercise and it is a sense of laziness for a lot of them too but that is another battle for another day.
They are all really lucky to have such great advocates in all of the groups. Again, thank you very much.
On that point, I thank all the witnesses from the bottom of my heart for all the expertise they have brought to the committee and for all they do as well. Thank you very much.

debateSection.summary: The joint committee adjourned at 2.39 p.m. until 12.30 p.m. on Thursday, 11 December 2025.
